Policy Description: The dot-com bubble inflated in the late 1990s, driven by speculation in internet companies, and burst in early 2000 after peaking on March 10, 2000. The Federal Reserve raised interest rates, which contributed to the bubble bursting, but there does not appear to be evidence of major federal bailouts or stimulus programs specifically for this sector.
The bursting of the dot-com bubble led to a recession in 2001, with GDP contracting and unemployment rising. However, there were no major federal stimulus or bailout programs implemented in response.

Policy Title: Coronavirus Aid Relief and Economic Security (CARES) Act
Policy Description: Provided more than $2 trillion in assistance, including stimulus checks of $1,200 per adult and $500 per child, expanded unemployment benefits, Paycheck Protection Program for small businesses.

$900 billion stimulus and relief bill with $600 direct payments per person, expanded unemployment benefits, small business loans, and funding for various sectors like transportation, public health, education.
$1.9 trillion package with $1,400 stimulus checks, extended unemployment benefits, aid to state/local governments, funding for COVID-19 response efforts.
Canceled up to $10,000 in federal student loan debt for individuals with incomes below $125,000 ($250,000 for couples), up to $20,000 for Pell Grant recipients.
